title: 111_hr3640
content: Homebuyer credit allowed for any purchase of principal residence. The amendment to section 36 of the Internal Revenue Code allows for the purchase of a principal residence to qualify for a homebuyer credit. The amendment specifies that the credit applies to only one sale or exchange of a principal residence by an individual, with a special rule for joint returns. The amendment to section 36 of the Internal Revenue Code reduces the credit for the purchase of a principal residence by the allowable amount, with a special rule for joint returns. Additionally, there are conforming amendments to redefine the definition of a first-time homebuyer and update related sections in the tax code. The amendments made by this section apply to residences purchased after the date of the enactment of this Act. The amendment extends the deadline for certain home purchases from December 1, 2009, to December 1, 2010. Taxpayers can elect to treat a home purchase after December 31, 2008, and before January 1, 2010, as made on December 31, 2008, or after December 31, 2009, and before December 1, 2010. The amendments extend the deadline for certain home purchases to December 1, 2010. Taxpayers can elect to treat a home purchase as made on December 31, 2009. The amendments take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 224. LOSS FROM SALE OF PRINCIPAL RESIDENCE. Part VII of subchapter B of chapter I of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section for deducting losses from the sale of a principal residence. Deduction for loss on sale of principal residence is allowed for individuals who have owned and used the property as their main home for at least 2 years in a 5-year period. The deduction is limited to $6,000 ($12,000 for joint returns) in total, with an annual limit of $2,000 ($4,000 for joint returns). The deduction for loss on the sale of a principal residence is limited to $2,000 ($4,000 for joint returns) annually. Any excess can be carried forward to the next two taxable years. Loss allocated to periods of nonqualified use is excluded from the deduction. Loss on the sale of a principal residence is limited to $2,000 ($4,000 for joint returns) annually, with any excess carried forward. Loss is allocated to periods of nonqualified use and excluded from the deduction. Subsection (a) does not apply to more than 1 sale of a principal residence. The section discusses rules for joint returns on the sale of a principal residence, including deductions allowable to spouses and applicable rules similar to section 121. Taxpayers can elect not to apply this section to a sale or exchange. The section allows for a deduction from the sale of a principal residence, with the provision that it does not apply after December 31, 2010. The amendments regarding the loss from the sale of a principal residence will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2008.
